instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PM_SLP_S5_L: What is PM_SLP_S5_L? PM_SLP_S5_L is a signal that, when 3.3v, turns on power rails that will wake the system from an S5 state. This signal is a part of the power management system of the MacBook.  The \"PM\" prefix typically stands for \"Power Management,\" and the \"SLP\" is for \"Sleep.\" The \"S5\" denotes the specific sleep state, which is Suspend to Disk, and the \"_L\" suffix indicates that this is an active low signal..
definitions.PP5V5_S5: What is PP5V5_S5? This is a typo of PP5V_S5 When you see PP5V_S5, assume they meant to type PP5V_S5.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PP1V5_S0: What is PP1V5_S0? PP1V5_S0 is a 1.5v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PP1V8_S3: What is PP1V8_S3? The PP1V8_S3 signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides a voltage of 1.8 volts during the S3 power state. The S3 state, often referred to as "suspend to RAM," is a low-power mode where the computer saves the session's state to RAM, allowing for quicker wake-up times compared to a full shutdown..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.4v
<SIGNAL>PP5V5_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>(replaced twice)
1,8 - 3.3v
all the rest 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 5v

<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v with trigger down to 0v then back to 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_BTLOW_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v 
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> 3.4vwith trigger down to 0v then back to 3.3v

<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S5_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP</SIGNAL>+<SIGNAL>S4_L</SIGNAL> 3.3v
 cpu getting hot(not to hot)

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
If you get <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, there should be S3 voltages present; like L7430, L7820.
Did you check <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> too?
If present, only then you can expect S0 voltages; check L7630 and page 58.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
L7430 1.2V
L7820 1.7V
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> 3.3V

L7630 1.1V
PAGE 58:
<SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0</SIGNAL> 0.5V
ALL THE REST LOOK FINE

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
It comes from <CHIP>U7870</CHIP>; post all its voltages.
Check diode mode to ground at <SIGNAL>1V5_S0</SIGNAL>.

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
Diode mode to ground at <RESISTOR>R8041</RESISTOR>?
You can check what happens removing <CHIP>U8040</CHIP>.
I recommend to try first disconnecting LIO flex.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
was corrosion on J9500.
<RESISTOR>R8041</RESISTOR> short on  <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0SW_AUDIO_HDA</SIGNAL>. NOT FROM <CAPACITOR>C1210</CAPACITOR> OR FROM <TRANSISTOR>Q1920</TRANSISTOR>. I THINK FROM CPU.
witout <RESISTOR>R8041</RESISTOR> fan spin, with is not..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message: turn no but of course no audio :(

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message: Post exact ohm resistance to ground at <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S0SW_AUDIO_HDA</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> wathr damage - GREEN/ORANGE no fan, bypass smc just fan full speed.
threads.message:
You can try to inject 1-2V (no more) there.
It will probably heat the PCH, without solving the problem; just for confirmation.

Look en Internet for portable USB speaker.
You should find some model specially designed for laptop, to attach on top of the screen.
